TextEquiv.Unicode: Study shows that chimpanzees work together, punish bad behavior
Chimpanzees are humans‘ closest living relative, and humans
love their playful ways and big smiles. Chimps are also thought
to have a less friendly side, though. Many people think they are

Chimpanzees are humans‘ closest living relative, and humans love their playful ways and big smiles. Chimps are also thought to have a less friendly side, though. Many people think they are combative and rough.
However, a new study shows that chimps may choose working
together over ﬁghting. When they do ﬁght, they are often tar-
geting a chimp that refuses to work with the team.
However, a new study shows that chimps may choose working together over ﬁghting. When they do ﬁght, they are often tar- geting a chimp that refuses to work with the team.
Scientists at Emory University studied 1 1 chimps in a large
sealed off area. They wanted to see ifthe chimps would cooper-
ate. They deﬁned cooperation as two or more chimps working
together to get a food reward.

Scientists at Emory University studied 1 1 chimps in a large sealed off area. They wanted to see ifthe chimps would cooper- ate. They deﬁned cooperation as two or more chimps working together to get a food reward.
At ﬁrst, two chimps had to team up. One had to lift up a barrier,
something that was in the way. Once the barrier was lifted, the
other chimp could reach a tray holding small pieces of fruit. Af-
ter two learned to work together, another object was put in the
way. The team needed a third chimp to pitch in if all three

At ﬁrst, two chimps had to team up. One had to lift up a barrier, something that was in the way. Once the barrier was lifted, the other chimp could reach a tray holding small pieces of fruit. Af- ter two learned to work together, another object was put in the way. The team needed a third chimp to pitch in if all three wanted to get the food.
The chimps had plenty of chances to compete. The scientists
deﬁned “competition" among the chimps as physical ﬁghting,
bullying, or freeloading. Freeloading is stealing the reward
without putting in the work of getting it.

The chimps had plenty of chances to compete. The scientists deﬁned “competition" among the chimps as physical ﬁghting, bullying, or freeloading. Freeloading is stealing the reward without putting in the work of getting it.
The scientists learned a lot from the study. The chimps worked
together much more often than they fought. In addition, when
The scientists learned a lot from the study. The chimps worked together much more often than they fought. In addition, when
one chimp tried to compete, the others tried to punish this be-
havior. They would work with their more group-focused and
one chimp tried to compete, the others tried to punish this be- havior. They would work with their more group-focused and cooperative fellow chimps, instead.
When the chimps did ﬁght, it was often to stop the overly com-
petitive chimps or to prevent a chimp from freeloading. The
chimps did not like it when other chimps tried to take what they
did not work for. Many times, the scientists saw a chimp step in

When the chimps did ﬁght, it was often to stop the overly com- petitive chimps or to prevent a chimp from freeloading. The chimps did not like it when other chimps tried to take what they did not work for. Many times, the scientists saw a chimp step in to punish ﬁeeloaders.
Plenty of other animals cooperate. Ants are one example. How-
ever, the lead scientist Malini Suchak explains that ants and
most other animals mostly help their family members. She says
the ants do not really think about what they are doing. They are
basically programmed to help their relatives. Her study shows
that the chimps are actually thinking about cooperation. What
the chimps do is much closer to human behavior than to the

Plenty of other animals cooperate. Ants are one example. How- ever, the lead scientist Malini Suchak explains that ants and most other animals mostly help their family members. She says the ants do not really think about what they are doing. They are basically programmed to help their relatives. Her study shows that the chimps are actually thinking about cooperation. What the chimps do is much closer to human behavior than to the ants’ behavior, she said.
